title: Cosmologist Rajendra Gupta visits Kerala University - The Hindu
Webb Telescope Spots Swirling Ribbons of Interstellar Medium - ExtremeTech
summary:
Webb Telescope Spots Swirling Ribbons of Interstellar Medium

Date: Recent Announcement
Source: NASA, ExtremeTech

NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has captured a stunning new view of the interstellar medium, showcasing the intricate dust and gas between stars, illuminated by the echoes of a long-gone star. The image reveals previously unseen structures within this elusive material.

  • The Webb Telescope provided a unique look at the interstellar medium, typically invisible to observers.
  • Light from a collapsed star allowed for visualization of ribbon-like swirls in the interstellar medium.
  • The image demonstrates structures within the interstellar medium smaller than ever observed before.
  • Webb's NIRCam performed a CT scan-like analysis to create a layered image.
"We did not know that the interstellar medium had structures on that small of a scale, let alone that it was sheet-like," says Josh Peek, a member of the Webb science team.

This groundbreaking image enhances our understanding of the interstellar medium and its complex structures, promising further insights as we continue to explore the cosmos.
newTitle: Webb Telescope Spots Swirling Ribbons of Interstellar Medium

title: 6 Very Beautiful Images Of Space Clicked By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Very Beautiful Images Of Space Clicked By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Jan 16, 2025 | Source: Times Now

The Hubble Space Telescope has captured breathtaking images of the cosmos. Here are 6 of the most beautiful pictures ever taken by this iconic observatory.

  • Ghost Nebula

    Located in the constellation Cassiopeia, illuminated by Gamma Cassiopeiae.

  • Westerlund 2

    A massive star cluster with 3,000 stars in the star-forming region Gum 29.

  • NGC 1850

    A 100-million-year-old globular cluster in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

  • Mystic Mountain

    Features a pillar of gas and dust, showcasing dynamic cosmic activity.

  • M83

    The Southern Pinwheel Galaxy, rich in active star formation.

  • NGC 1300

    A textbook example of a barred spiral galaxy with a distinctive structure.

“The Hubble Space Telescope has truly transformed our understanding of the universe.”

This collection showcases the beauty and complexity of the universe, inspiring further exploration and appreciation of space.
newTitle: Stunning Space Captures by NASA's Hubble Telescope

title: Sunita Williams steps out on spacewalk after seven months in orbit - The Hindu
Rare planetary parade: Check dates and here's how you can see six or seven planets. Skywatching tips from - The Economic Times
summary:
Rare planetary parade: Check dates and here's how you can see six or seven planets

Publication Date: January 2025 - Source: Economic Times

This January, skygazers can look forward to a rare planetary parade where six planets—Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Neptune, and Uranus—will be visible in the night sky at the same time.

Key Points:

  • A planetary parade occurs when multiple planets appear aligned from Earth’s perspective.
  • The event is set to occur on January 21, with visibility starting from January 15.
  • The best viewing time is expected to be just after sunset around 8:30 p.m. local time.
  • A telescope may be required to spot Uranus and Neptune.
  • The parade will evolve into a seven-planet display when Mercury joins on February 29.
“Tonight it is a big one, Mars... It is directly opposite the sun, so it's going to rise at sunset, be visible all night...” - Greg Redfern, NASA/JPL Solar System Ambassador

This spectacular event provides a unique opportunity for astronomy enthusiasts to observe multiple planets in the sky simultaneously, making it a memorable experience for the month.
newTitle: Upcoming Rare Planetary Parade: Skywatching Tips and Dates

title: Rare planetary parade: Check dates and here's how you can see six or seven planets. Skywatching tips from NASA - The Economic Times
NASA's stuck astronaut steps out on a spacewalk after 7 months in orbit - The Albertan
summary:
NASA's Astronaut Suni Williams Completes Spacewalk After Seven Months in Orbit

Date: March 21, 2023

Source: The Associated Press

NASA astronaut Suni Williams stepped out for her first spacewalk after being in orbit for more than seven months, assisting with overdue outdoor repairs on the International Space Station.

  • Williams is the station's commander and completed her eighth spacewalk.
  • She performed the spacewalk alongside NASA's Nick Hague.
  • Williams and fellow astronaut Butch Wilmore are expected to float back out next week.
  • This spacewalk marks the first since an aborted attempt last summer due to a water leak issue.
  • NASA has resolved the cooling loop problem that caused the previous delay.
“It was the first spacewalk by NASA astronauts since an aborted one last summer.”

This successful spacewalk signifies a positive step forward for NASA's ongoing operations and showcases the resilience of its astronauts during extended missions.
newTitle: NASA's Astronaut Suni Williams Completes Spacewalk After Seven Months in Orbit

title: Astronomers Discover Unusual X-Ray Oscillations From a Black Hole 100 Million Light-Years Away - Passionategeekz
summary:
Astronomers Discover Unusual X-Ray Oscillations From a Black Hole 100 Million Light-Years Away

Publication Date: Not specified Source: phys.org

A supermassive black hole located in a galaxy 100 million light-years away has been observed showing unusual X-ray oscillations, marking a significant discovery in the study of black holes.

  • The frequency of X-ray flashes increased from 18 minutes to seven minutes over two years.
  • The black hole, named 1ES 1927+654, has drawn attention for its unique behavior.
  • Researchers from MIT suggest that the oscillations may originate from a compact white dwarf orbiting near the black hole's event horizon.
  • The white dwarf may shed material into the black hole, affecting its dynamics without crossing the event horizon.
  • Future observatories like NASA’s LISA could potentially detect the gravitational waves produced by this phenomenon.
“Such proximity to a black hole without falling in has not been observed before.” - Megan Masterson

Continued observations are anticipated to shed further light on the interactions between black holes and their surrounding celestial objects.
newTitle: Astronomers Discover Unusual X-Ray Oscillations From a Black Hole 100 Million Light-Years Away

summary:
Astronomers Discover Unusual X-Ray Oscillations From a Black Hole

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] | Source: [Insert Source Here]

A supermassive black hole, located 100 million light-years away, has shown unusual behavior with increasing X-ray flash frequencies over two years.

  • Frequency of X-ray flashes started at 18 minutes and accelerated to seven minutes.
  • The black hole 1ES 1927+654 may have a white dwarf in a precarious orbit.
  • Discovery presented at the 245th American Astronomical Society meeting.
  • Potential detection of gravitational waves from the white dwarf's orbit is anticipated.
  • Further observations planned to understand black hole dynamics.
Megan Masterson: “Such proximity to a black hole without falling in has not been observed before.”

title: Scientists leverage AI to develop an opener for a molecular can - INDIAai
A copper catalyst can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into acetaldehyde - Tech Explorist
summary:
Copper Catalyst Improves CO2 Conversion to Acetaldehyde

Publication Date: 03 January 2025 Source: Nature Synthesis

The article discusses a novel copper-based catalyst that efficiently converts carbon dioxide (CO2) into acetaldehyde, presenting a promising alternative to traditional manufacturing processes. This breakthrough could significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions while providing a critical industrial chemical.

  • The copper catalyst achieves a remarkable 92% selectivity for acetaldehyde, outperforming existing methods.
  • This method addresses the limitations of the conventional Wacker process, relying on non-renewable resources and resulting in high carbon emissions.
  • The design utilized spark ablation to create small, precise copper clusters, enhancing efficiency and stability.
  • The catalyst maintains its performance over extended periods, showcasing its potential for industrial applications.
  • Ongoing research could lead to broader applications, transforming chemical production.
“The Wacker process has remained largely unchanged for the past 60 years. It was time for a green breakthrough,” said Koolen.

The development of this copper catalyst represents a significant advancement in sustainable chemistry, paving the way for greener industrial practices.
newTitle: Copper Catalyst Improves CO2 Conversion to Acetaldehyde

The recent Instagram post by NASA featured a close-up of a sandhill crane, leading many to speculate if their account had been hacked. However, the post emphasizes the diverse wildlife found at the Kennedy Space Center.

  • The post displayed a photo of a redheaded sandhill crane with its large brown eyes.
  • This was part of NASA's effort to highlight the wildlife at its facilities.
  • Followers were initially confused by the non-space related image.
  • The caption clarified the bird is one of 1,500 species residing at Kennedy Space Center.
  • No evidence of a cybersecurity breach was found.
“This sandhill crane is one of the 1,500 different species of plants and animals that make their home at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.”

This incident highlights NASA's commitment to environmental awareness while engaging with their audience in a creative way.

summary:
Mars Satellite Images Reveal Giant 'Kidney Beans,' Sparking Hints of Water and Life

Date: Not specified Source: Gadgets 360

Recent observations of frozen dunes on Mars suggest the potential presence of water and microbial life in the planet's past.

  • Frozen sand dunes observed by NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter are stationary due to carbon dioxide frost.
  • Understanding these features can help scientists determine if Mars once had conditions suitable for liquid water.
  • The Martian axial tilt may have supported a thicker atmosphere in the past, impacting its climate.
  • Research on frost patterns aids in uncovering Mars' climatic history and possible habitability.
“Studying these frost-covered dunes helps scientists assess whether liquid water was present on Mars for periods long enough to support life.”

These findings deepen our understanding of Mars' climate evolution and its implications for astrobiology.
newTitle: Mars Satellite Images Reveal Giant 'Kidney Beans,' Sparking Hints of Water and Life

Date: January 16, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

Astronaut Don Pettit captured breathtaking footage of Comet ATLAS from the International Space Station as it made its closest approach to the Sun.

  • The comet, officially named C/2024 G3, is 87 million miles away from Earth.
  • Pettit described seeing the comet from orbit as "totally amazing."
  • Experts predict Comet ATLAS to be the brightest comet of the year.
"It is totally amazing to see a comet from orbit. Atlas C2024-G3 is paying us a visit." - Don Pettit

Comets are ancient remnants that form glowing tails as they approach the Sun, creating spectacular sights in the sky.

title: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Shows 3D Structure Of Dust And Gas Between Stars - NDTV
Watch 2 NASA astronauts repair X-ray telescope on ISS during a spacewalk today - Space.com
summary:
Watch 2 NASA astronauts repair X-ray telescope on ISS during a spacewalk today

Date: January 16, 2023 | Source: Space.com

Today, two NASA astronauts, Nick Hague and Suni Williams, will perform the first spacewalk of the year to repair the NICER X-ray telescope aboard the International Space Station (ISS).

  • The spacewalk is set to begin around 8:00 a.m. EST and last approximately 6.5 hours.
  • NASA will stream the spacewalk live, starting at 6:30 a.m. EST.
  • The astronauts will patch light leaks in the NICER telescope and prepare the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer for upgrades.
  • This marks the first on-orbit repair of a NASA space telescope since 2009.
“The experienced spacewalking duo will also replace advanced engineering hardware to maintain station orientation and provide navigation data.”

In May 2023, NICER developed light leaks that are now set to be fixed during this mission. This demonstrates the ongoing need for maintenance of scientific instruments in space.
newTitle: NASA Astronauts Conduct Spacewalk to Repair X-ray Telescope

SpaceX Launches Two Private Lunar Landers: A Milestone for Lunar Exploration and NASA’s Long-Term Lunar Am - The Economic Times
summary:
SpaceX Launches Two Private Lunar Landers: A Milestone for Lunar Exploration and NASA’s Long-Term Lunar Ambitions

Last Updated: 15 January, 2025 | The Feed

SpaceX has achieved another remarkable milestone with the launch of two private lunar landers, Blue Ghost and Resilience, setting the stage for groundbreaking advancements in lunar exploration.

  • SpaceX launched two private lunar landers on January 15, 2025.
  • Blue Ghost, developed by Firefly Aerospace, will land in Mare Crisium after a system check in Earth orbit.
  • Resilience, developed by ispace, will deploy a micro rover to collect lunar samples.
  • These missions support NASA's Artemis program to establish a sustainable human presence on the Moon.
  • The launch reflects the growing role of private companies in space exploration.
“These missions are integral to NASA's Artemis program, which aims to establish a sustainable human presence on the Moon by the decade's end.”

The launch of Blue Ghost and Resilience marks a significant step forward in lunar exploration, highlighting private sector contributions to future space missions.
newTitle: SpaceX Launches Two Private Lunar Landers: A Milestone for Lunar Exploration

title: How the Brain Uses Place Cells to Anchor Episodic Memories - Neuroscience News
summary:
How the Brain Uses Place Cells to Anchor Episodic Memories

Date & Source: Publication Date: Today, Source: MIT

Researchers have developed a model explaining how place cells in the hippocampus anchor both spatial and episodic memories. The new model addresses phenomena like gradual memory degradation and the memorization technique of memory palaces.

  • Memory Mechanism: Place and grid cells form a scaffold linking spatial and episodic memories.
  • Memory Accuracy: The model explains gradual memory decay and sequential recall, avoiding “memory cliffs.”
  • Memory Palaces: It mirrors how associating memories with spatial environments strengthens recall.
“This model is a first-draft model of the entorhinal-hippocampal episodic memory circuit. It’s a foundation to build on to understand the nature of episodic memory. That’s the thing I’m really excited about,” says Ila Fiete, a professor of brain and cognitive sciences at MIT.

The model captures memory phenomena much more accurately than existing models, offering insights into both spatial and episodic memories.
newTitle: How the Brain Uses Place Cells to Anchor Episodic Memories

title: Deccan eruptions: How lava sparked a tropical floral revival - India Today
summary:
Deccan Eruptions: How Lava Sparked a Tropical Floral Revival

Published On: Jan 15, 2025

Source: Rivanshi Rakhrai

The study reveals that while Deccan Volcanism caused significant disasters for fauna, its effects on flora were only short-term and regional.

  • Deccan Volcanism identified as a cause of mass extinctions around 66 million years ago.
  • Volcanic activities may have facilitated the growth and diversification of tropical plants.
  • Extinction of certain species created an undisturbed environment for angiosperms to thrive.
  • The research suggests rapid recovery of tropical rainforests under favorable conditions.
  • Methods used include palynology and detailed analysis of sedimentary rocks.
  • Insights can help predict ecosystems’ responses to global warming.
“This knowledge could prove critical in predicting how ecosystems might react to ongoing global warming and other environmental stresses.”

The findings underscore the resilience of tropical ecosystems and their potential for recovery, highlighting the complex interplay between geological events and ecological responses.
newTitle: Deccan Eruptions: How Lava Sparked a Tropical Floral Revival
